newsitem.title: BELGIUM: New EU rules for imports of U.S. poultry apply now.
newsitem.headline: New EU rules for imports of U.S. poultry apply now.

text.p: New veterinary controls on European Union imports of about $50 million worth of poultry meat a year from the United States apply from today (Tuesday), European Commission agriculture spokesman Gerard Kiely said.

Kiely was commenting after EU and U.S. negotiators failed to settle a long-running dispute over meat and poultry inspection methods before an April 1 deadline for introducing common rules in the 15 EU member states.
"We are not satisfied their products meet our standards," Kiely told a news briefing, adding, "The Community certificate system applies from today."
"We are putting in place a system which allows trade to continue and protects consumers and health standards."
None of the U.S. poultry slaughter houses recently inspected by EU veterinary officials met EU standards, Kiely noted.
Washington does not accept some of the EU standards and argues that its rules are too strict.
Kiely said EU negotiators were still in Washington and could resume talks on an agreement which would allow each side to accept products from the other even if their inspection methods differed.
EU rules apply at every stage of processing whereas the U.S. targets the final product.
The EU signed in December a so-called veterinary equivalency agreement with New Zealand and has concluded similar deals with Canada and the Czech Republic.
Kiely said that the EU and U.S. had agreed on standards for red meat and pigmeat and also for about 80 percent of U.S. petfood exports to the EU worth a total of $150 million annually.
Asked about Danish pigmeat exports to the U.S., Kiely said that trade was continuing normally.
